title: Welcome
body: This module is going to detail the meaning of statistical significance and how this relates to clinical significance in practice. This can be daunting but is crucial in your day-to-day practise as an optometrist. The module will help navigate you through this area.

title: ILOs
body:
Upon completion of this module, you will be able to:

  • Understand variability of measures and the role of repeatability/reliability in interpreting results.
  • Interpret a Bland and Altman plot
  • Understand the importance of sensitivity and specificity values.
  • Determine the difference between statistical significance and clinical significance.
  • Describe potential limitations to statistically significant results.

title: Repeatability
body:
Repeatability of measurements (precision) refers to the variation in repeat measurements made on the same subject under identical conditions. To get precise results, you must be able to perform the same procedure multiple times.

Ideally, the same researcher conducts the same procedure using the same materials and measuring instruments under the same environmental conditions and does all the trials in a short period of time.

For example, when measuring ETDRS LogMAR visual acuity a two-line change in this measure would be considered statistically significantly different from baseline, based upon published repeatability measures. Similarly in the case of retinoscopy, a change of 0.50 DS would be considered significantly different.

Variability in measurements made on the same subject in a repeatability study can then be ascribed only to errors due to the measurement process itself where all other factors are controlled.

title: Reliability
body:
Reliability relates the magnitude of the measurement error in observed measurements to the inherent variability in the ‘error-free’, ‘true’, or underlying level of the quantity (terms we shall use synonymously) between subjects.

If measurement errors tend to be large compared with the true differences between subjects, reliability will be low because differences between measurements of two subjects could be due purely to error rather than to a genuine difference in their true values. But if reliability is high, measurement errors are small in comparison to the true differences between subjects, so that subjects can be relatively well distinguished.

The reliability parameter is also known as an intraclass correlation (ICC), as it is the correlation between any two measurements made on the same subject. Reliability takes values between zero and one, with a value of one corresponding to zero measurement error and a value of zero meaning that all the variability in measurements is due to measurement error.

title: Agreement Between Methods
body: Before we use a new measurement method or technique in clinical practice, we must ensure that the measurements it gives are ‘sufficiently similar’ to those generated by the measurement method currently used, i.e., that measurements made with the old method are reproducible using the new method.

title: Linear Association
body: This study shows the strength of linear association between PT100 (non-contact tonometer) compared to Goldmann Applanation Tonometry (GAT) (contact tonometer) which is the reference standard.

title: Mean Difference
body: While examining the relationship between measures from two devices with simple correlation and linear regression is convenient, it does not provide quantitative information on agreement between two measures. This quantitative assessment of the agreement between measurements from two methods/ instruments is often more easily and appropriately done by plotting the difference of each subject's measurements from the two methods against the mean of their measurements. This is called a mean difference plot, commonly referred to in medical statistics as the Bland–Altman plot and is frequently seen in publications of measurement error studies.

title: Test your knowledge
body: The solid line indicates the mean of the paired differences; its distance from zero provides an estimate of the systematic bias between the two methods. The dashed lines indicate the estimated limits of agreement (LOA). The LOA give a range within which we expect 95% of differences in measurements between the two methods to lie. To estimate them, we first calculate the mean and SD of the paired differences.\[Upper\,LOA=mean\,difference+1.96\times SD\] \[Lower\,LOA=mean\,difference-1.96\times SD\]

title: Sensitivity and Specificity
body: To determine a particular tests ability to diagnose a certain pathology or to detect a particular sign of the presence of the disease (e.g., reduced visual function), it is pertinent to examine the sensitivity and specificity of a test alongside reported confidence intervals. This can be done by performing the test on a group of individuals with the known pathology for example glaucoma.

title: Sensitivity
body: Sensitivity is the proportion of subjects with the pathology that are correctly identified by the test. \[Sensitivity = True\, positives/ all\, those\, with\, the\, pathology\]

title: Specificity
body: Specificity is the proportion of subjects without the pathology that are correctly identified by the test. \[Specificity= True\, negatives/ all\, those\, without\, the\, pathology\]

title: Specificity
body: A test with high sensitivity but low specificity will have high levels of false positives, greater referrals, more cost and time burdens, and patients with undue worries. Whereas a test with high specificity and low sensitivity will have higher false negatives, leading to no diagnosis of pathology or late diagnosis of pathology if the test is repeated. Ideally sensitivity and specificity are high, but in practice a cut-off is selected as a compromise between the two to optimise the balance between sensitivity and specificity (Saunders et al., 2015).

Often the performance of a diagnostic test can be evaluated using receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves. These are a plot of the test sensitivity between 0 – 1 (where 0 = poor sensitivity and 1 = perfect sensitivity) and 1-specificity (where 0 = optimal specificity and 1 = poor specificity). The area under the ROC curve provides a summary measure of the overall test performance, it being suggested that an ROC >0.8 is required as a minimum for a diagnostic test. ROC curves illustrating (a) high sensitivity & high specificity, and (b) low sensitivity and low specificity may be seen below.
Below  is an example of an ROC curve using intraocular pressure (IOP) cut-offs to screen for glaucoma.

title: Statistical vs Clinical Significance
body: In clinical research, study results which are statistically significant are often interpreted as being clinically important. While statistical significance indicates the reliability of the study results, clinical significance reflects its impact on clinical practice.
instruction: Click the cards to see more information.

description.title: Statistical Significance
description.body: Statistical significance quantifies the probability of a study's results being due to chance.

description.title: Clinical Significance
description.body: Clinical significance refers to the magnitude of the actual treatment effect (i.e., the difference between the intervention and control groups, also known as the “treatment effect size”), which will determine whether the results of the trial are likely to impact current clinical practice.

title: p-value
body: The p-value, frequently used to measure statistical significance, is the probability that the study results are due to chance rather than to a real treatment effect/ difference between groups. The conventional cut off for the p-value to be considered statistically significant is 0.05 (or 5%). A p<0.05 implies that the possibility of the results in a study being due to chance is <5% (less than a one in twenty chance).

However, there are flaws and misconceptions to the meaning of p-values as discussed by Goodman (2011), which are listed below. Most notable is point 3, “A statistically significant finding is clinically important”. A statistically significant result does not mean the finding is clinically important. The difference could be too small to be clinically important. Firstly, the p-value carries no information about the magnitude of an effect. This would be indicated by the effect estimate (effect size) and/ or confidence interval. Second, the end point may itself not be clinically important, as it could occur with some surrogate outcomes.

Table 1 Twelve P-Value Misconceptions
1.If P = .05, the null hypothesis has only a 5% chance of being true.
2.A nonsignificant difference (eg, P ≥.05) means there is no difference between groups.
3.A statistically significant finding is clinically important.
4.Studies with P values on opposite sides of .05 are conflicting.
5.Studies with the same P value provide the same evidence against the null hypothesis.
6.P = .05 means that we have observed data that would occur only 5% of the time under the null hypothesis.
7.P = .05 and P ≤.05 mean the same thing.
8.P values are properly written as inequalities (eg, “P ≤.02” when P = .015)
9.P = .05 means that if you reject the null hypothesis, the probability of a type I error is only 5%.
10.With a P = .05 threshold for significance, the chance of a type I error will be 5%.
11.You should use a one-sided P value when you don’t care about a result in one direction, or a difference in that direction is impossible.
12.A scientific conclusion or treatment policy should be based on whether or not the P value is significant.

instruction: Click open the link to the paper.

body: The magnitude of an observed effect and the uncertainty regarding it should always be considered when interpreting statistical evidence. Whenever possible, a statistical analysis which produces an effect size estimate with associated uncertainty (difference in means and its confidence intervals) rather than solely a p value should be used and reported (Cook et al., 2015).

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody:
Statistical significance is not the same as clinical significance. Bad data at home can mislead, which is why it's important to look at the outcomes of cardiovascular trials. Researchers should drop preconceived notions and instead focus on the testicular test. My upbringing in clinical trial results can differ in terms of the range of possible results, as defined by confidence intervals, which should be considered when making clinical recommendations.

Investigators often use data from cohort studies that have found each variable to be significantly important. For example, a medication may significantly improve a patient's health, or computer algorithms may identify new surgical techniques that are significantly better than the current treatment being used. The answer to this question is not as straightforward as one might think; a single figure in the calculations can make the results more meaningful, but what happens next is more effective treatment that is considered vital to showing significant results.

Researchers should not shy away from these discoveries, as statistical significance does not necessarily suggest that the researchers have found clinical relevance. Directing this critical analysis toward thousands of potential clinical studies, a team of Canadian researchers focused on cardiovascular trials. They examined study design, p-values, and the primary outcomes. They found that almost three-quarters of trials reported statistically significant results.

According to the new study, however, sixty percent of these cases had high potential for actual clinical implications, despite statistical analyses finding them to be insignificant. Just because a medical treatment has not reached statistical significance doesn't rule out the possibility that it may be beneficial or harmful. We must look beyond p-values.

Researchers run the risk of missing potentially useful results that affect research teams. The research team suggests adopting a broader view in which all potential meaningful effects are considered before making clinical recommendations.

title: Correlation and Linear Regression
body: Pearson’s Correlation Coefficient (r) measures the strength of linear association between two continuous variables. The values range from -1 to 1. Zero indicates no association between variables, with a value closer to 1 or –1 indicating a stronger relationship. A positive value indicates a positive association, as the value of one variable increase so does the value of the other variable. A negative value indicates a negative association, as the value of one variable increases the value of the other decreases.
Select the r value that matches the correlation between the variables.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct: Excellent, you have selected the correct r values.

_incorrect.final: At least one of your choice was not correct.

_partlyCorrect.final: This feedback will appear if you answered part of the question correctly.

body: Linear regression analysis allows for a more formal description of the association between two variables. If we know what are the independent (x-axis) and dependent (y-axis) variables together with their units, we can estimate the value of the dependent variable as a function of the independent variable using the equation y = a + bx (where a = intercept and b = slope/regression coefficient).  The regression coefficient can also be known as effect size, parameter estimate or Beta coefficient.

title: Optometry Example
body:
There is a strong statistically significant positive linear relationship between central corneal thickness and IOP values, r=0.44, p<0.05.

Therefore, we expect higher IOPs in those with thicker corneas (>565 µm) and if a IOP reading is borderline with a thick cornea it could be considered normal.

title: Optometry Example
body: Regression models allow adjustment for other cofounders that might explain any associations we see e.g., multivariable analysis. The unadjusted and adjusted results are both presented. Linear regression can be used to explore associations when the outcome is continuous. Logistic regression can be used to exposure associations when the outcome of interest is binary. Exposure variables can be any type of data for either regression type.

title: Optometry Example
body:
There is a strong statistically significant positive linear relationship between a child’s height and their axial length after controlling for age and ethnicity, F=0.536, p=0.032.

There are 3.25 times greater odds of having AMD in those people who are older, have a family history of AMD and smoke.

title: Risks and odds
body:
Risk is the probability that an event will occur. Risk = number of new cases with outcome/number initially without outcome.

Risk ratio (RR)= risk of outcome in exposed/ risk of outcome in unexposed.

Risk ratio is a relative measure of the strength of association between exposure and outcome e.g., smokers are 2 times more likely to develop age-related macular degeneration (AMD).

title: Cards
instruction: Click the cards to see more information.

description.title: RR<1
description.body: Suggests exposure is associated with decrease in outcome, e.g., RR 0.47, 0.47 times more likely to experience outcome or 53% decrease in risk.

description.title: RR=1
description.body: The risks are identical in exposed and unexposed groups. There is no association.

description.title: RR>1
description.body: Suggests exposure is associated with an increase in outcome e.g., RR of 1.8, 1.8 times more likely to experience outcome or 80% increase in risk.

title: Slider
body: Position the slider to the position corresponding to a Risk Ratio of 1.9
ariaQuestion: On a sliding scale from 100% decrease in risk to 100% increase in risk, what would be the percentage corresponding to a Risk Ratio of 1.9?

title: Slider
body: Position the slider to the position corresponding to a Risk Ratio of 1.25
ariaQuestion: On a sliding scale from 100% decrease in risk to 100% increase in risk, what would be the percentage corresponding to a Risk Ratio of 1.25?

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct: Well done. The increase in risk corresponding to a Risk Ratio of 1.25 is 25%.

_incorrect.final: You didn't quite get the right answer. The increase in risk corresponding to a Risk Ratio of 1.25 is 25%.

title: Slider
body: Position the slider to the position corresponding to a Risk Ratio of 0.45
ariaQuestion: On a sliding scale from 100% decrease in risk to 100% increase in risk, what would be the percentage corresponding to a Risk Ratio of 0.45?

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct: Well done. A Risk Ratio of 0.45 corresponds to a decrease in risk of 55%.

_incorrect.final: You didn't quite get the right answer. The decrease in risk corresponding to a Risk Ratio of 0.45 is 55%.

title: Slider
body: Position the slider to the position corresponding to a Risk Ratio of 1.00
ariaQuestion: On a sliding scale from 100% decrease in risk to 100% increase in risk, what would be the percentage corresponding to a Risk Ratio of 1.00?

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct: Well done. A Risk Ratio of 1.00 corresponds to a decrease or increase in risk of 0% (no association).

_incorrect.final: You didn't quite get the right answer. For a Risk Ratio of 1.00, there is no decrease or increase in risk (no association).

title: Slider
body: Position the slider to the position corresponding to a Risk Ratio of 0.35
ariaQuestion: On a sliding scale from 100% decrease in risk to 100% increase in risk, what would be the percentage corresponding to a Risk Ratio of 0.35?

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct: Well done. A Risk Ratio of 0.35 corresponds to a decrease in risk of 65%.

_incorrect.final: You didn't quite get the right answer. For a Risk Ratio of 0.35, there is a decrease in risk of 65%.

title: Confidence intervals
body:
Confidence intervals and p-values are presented with risk ratios, but we must remember that association may not be causal. \[Risk\,Difference=Risk\,of\,outcome\,in\,exposed-Risk\,of\,outcome\,in\,unexposed\]
Risk difference measures the impact of exposure in units by comparing the absolute differences e.g., for every 100 smokers there will be an extra 30people with AMD.\[Odds= \frac{number\,with\,outcome}{number\,without\,outcome}\]
For more rare conditions risk and odds are similar but for more common conditions odds are higher than risk. \[Odds Ratio (OR)= \frac{odds\,of\,outcome\,in\,exposed}{odds\,of\,outcome\,in\,unexposed}\]
Logistic Regression is an extension of a simple odds ratio where additional exposures can be controlled for e.g., age or gender. Usually when controlling for cofounders the OR’s will reduce (closer to 1).

title: Optometry example
body: Primary school students who spent <1 hour per day outdoors had 1.87 times the risk of myopia development compared to those who spent >3 hours per day outdoors. This correlates to an 87% increase in risk of myopia development in those spending <1 hour outdoors compared to those spending >3 hours outdoors.

_items.title: Statistical tests assume a null hypothesis of no relationship or no difference between groups. Then determine whether the observed data fall outside of the range of values predicted by the null hypothesis.
T-tests are paired (repeated measures) or unpaired (independent). ANOVA compares 3 or more groups.
Chi-Squared testing explores relationships between categorical variables.
Linear regression can be used to explore associations when the outcome is continuous. Logistic regression can be used to explore associations when the outcome of interest is binary.

title: Assessment
body:
To get accreditation for this learning module, complete the following assessment. Questions will display one at a time and you will 3 attempts for each question. To move from one question to the next, select the Continue button at the bottom of the screen.
This assessment consists of 5 questions.
